prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G15ETG
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Dusty ETG in GAMA field G15

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We wish to detect the 12CO(2-1) line, using Band 6 observations, in order to spatially resolve the molecular gas and to measure kinematics of the gas from this line. For this we have chosen, in baseband-1, a resolution of 1.3 km/s which will give us a S/N well above 5 per beam, per channel, since our exposure times are driven by the continuum limits. This will be sufficient to measure the velocity dispersion of the gas and will allow us to achieve high spectral resolution in the CO line. The resulting data rate is well within acceptable limits for Cycle 3. For our cold dust detection and spatial mapping we need as much waveband coverage as possible to maximize the signal. Therefore the remaining 3 spectral regions are being used for this dust mapping at 230 GHz.

Our choice of observed frequency is motivated by the spatial extent of the sources being well-matched to the spatial resolution and maximum resolvable scale available in ALMA band 6. Molecular gas in ETGs is typically found to have a radial extent of about Re/2 (Young et al.2011, Davis et al. 2013). Therefore we expect the molecular gas and dust in our ETGs (major axis Re approximately 4" - 10" - see Table 1) to be within the field-of-view (26") at 230 GHz in one single pointing. A spatial resolution of 0.6" (corresponding to scales of 500 pc at z=0.04) will allow us to resolve the extent of any molecular gas and dust disks in these H-ATLAS detected ETGs, plus detect any asymmetries in their distributions. We will be sensitive to emission on scales of up to 10", which is the maximum half-light radius of sources in our sample (we expect gas to be within Re/2). Our sources are not expected to contain emission on larger scales (they are not resolved in the Herschel-ATLAS observations). Therefore we do not require use of the ACA for these proposed observations. We have no special requirements on bandpass accuracy, data rates, scheduling or calibration.

Our primary goal is to detect the dust distributions and our exposure time estimates are thus driven by the dust continuum flux limits in these early-type galaxies. Three spectral windows will record continuum in three 1.875 GHz windows in 31 MHz (40 km/s) channels. The continuum flux is estimated from a modified blackbody fit to the 100-500micron fluxes, assuming a dust emissivity index of 2.0. The RMS values assume that the dust is resolved into 20 beams covering this source, with a signal-to-noise of 5 per beam. Our sample selects against AGN therefore the dust continuum is unlikely to be contaminated by radio synchrotron emission in these galaxies. One 1.875 GHz spectral window will cover the 12CO(2-1) line (centred on the redshift of the single target in this SG), with dual-polarisation 976kHz (1.3 km/s) channels. This ensures that we have at least 14 channels across the width of the CO line, assuming we smooth to 10 km/s channels. This is sufficient to measure the velocity and velocity dispersion of the gas and to allow for fine spectral resolution if the CO line is as strong as predicted. We estimated the mass of molecular hydrogen in our ETGs using the measured dust masses from H-ATLAS detections and assuming a conservative gas-to-dust ratio of 50. We estimate the peak CO flux assuming a Galactic XCO factor and a line width of 150 km/s (Young et al. 2011). Our RMS estimates assume a 12CO(2-1)/12CO(1-0) ratio of 1 (Young et al. 2011) and that we will resolve the CO line over 20 beams in each channel. Our sensitivity estimates should ensure an accurate measurement of the distributions of dust and molecular gas that is central to our science goals. Our targets are grouped so that sources within an individual science goal are within 10 degrees of each other and also share similar sensitivity requirements.

Our targets are grouped so that sources within an individual science goal are within 10 degrees of each other and also share similar sensitivity requirements.

Our targets are grouped so that sources within an individual science goal are within 10 degrees of each other and also share similar sensitivity requirements.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Second dusty ETG in GAMA field G12

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Early-type galaxies were once thought to be simple systems, with a lack of cold interstellar medium, but are now known to harbour gas, dust and star formation in many cases. This may form the basis of discovering how they evolve into the elliptical and lenticular galaxies in the local Universe. This application aims to measure the distribution and survivability of dust and molecular gas in a small sample of early-type galaxies with dust detections from Herschel space telescope at unexpectedly high levels (>2 x 10^7 Msun), comparable to spirals of similar mass. Whilst Herschel detected these sources, ALMA will resolve their emission from dust and molecular gas, and we will be able to measure the kinematics in the molecular gas. Any asymmetries in the gas and dust will be revealed, indicating a merger origins for the dust. We will test the spatial coincidence of the dust emission with the gas and hence test if it is shrouded from sputtering. Using spatially resolved radiative transfer programmes we will measure dust opacity, given the dust extents. Expected dust heating from the stellar populations will be obtained from application of the radiative transfer modelling.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Project code=2013.1.00386.S, Title="The origin of dust in early-type galaxies.", PI=Kate Rowlands.
